Description: The Justice Department reached an agreement with Abercrombie & Fitch Inc. resolving a complaint filed with the Office of Special Counsel for Immigration-Related Unfair Employment Practices claiming that the company discriminated against a non-U.S. citizen in violation of the Immigration and Nationality Act.

The Justice Department announced an agreement with Advantage Home Care LLC, a home health care provider based in Hackensack, N.J., resolving claims that the company violated the anti-discrimination provision of the Immigration and Nationality Act when it required newly-hired lawful permanent residents to provide more or different documents during the Form I-9 employment eligibility verification process.

Company: AIG Federal Savings Bank and Wilmington Finance Inc.
Description: Two subsidiaries of American International Group Inc. agreed to pay a minimum of $6.1 million to resolve allegations that they engaged in a pattern or practice of discrimination against African American borrowers.

The Justice Department reached a settlement with American Cleaning Company resolving claims that the company discriminated against work-authorized non-U.S. citizens in violation of the Immigration and Nationality Act.

Company: Auto Fare Inc. and Southeastern Auto Corp.
Description: The U.S. Department of Justice Civil Rights Division, the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Western District of North Carolina and the North Carolina Department of Justice announced a settlement of the federal government's first-ever discrimination lawsuit involving  "buy here, pay here" auto lending.

Company: Autobuses Ejecutivos LLC dba Omnibus Express
Description: The Justice Department reached a settlement with Autobuses Ejecutivos LLC, doing business as Omnibus Express, a bus company based in Houston, resolving a lawsuit filed in August 2013 by the department under the Immigration and Nationality Act's antidiscrimination provision.

Company: Autobuses Ejecutivos LLC dba Omnibus Express
Description: A Houston bus company was fined $55,000 for violating passenger carrier accessibility requirements under the Americans with Disabilities Act.

The Justice Department reached a settlement with Avant Healthcare Professionals LLC, a healthcare staffing company based in Casselberry, Fla. , resolving allegations that the company posted discriminatory job advertisements on the internet.

The Justice Department reached a settlement with BAE Systems Ship Repair Inc., a leading provider of ship repair services, to settle allegations that its subsidiary, BAE Systems Southeast Shipyards Alabama LLC, engaged in a pattern or practice of discrimination by imposing unnecessary and additional documentary requirements on work-authorized non-U.S. citizens when establishing their eligibility to work in the United States.

Bank of America N.A. agreed to maintain revised policies, conduct employee training and pay compensation to victims to resolve allegations that it engaged in a pattern or practice of discrimination on the basis of disability and receipt of public assistance in violation of the Fair Housing Act and the Equal Credit Opportunity Act.

The Justice Department reached an agreement with Barrios Street Realty Inc. resolving claims that the company and its agent, Jorge Arturo Guerrero Rodriguez, discriminated against U.S. workers by preferring to hire foreign workers under the H-2B visa program.

Company: B.C. Enterprises Inc. d/b/a Aristocrat Towing and Aristocrat Towing Inc.
Description: The Justice Department reached a settlement of alleged violations of the Servicemembers Civil Relief Act providing damages and credit repair to 26 servicemembers whose cars were towed and sold while they were on active duty without obtaining court orders as SCRA requires.

Bland Farms in Reidsville, Georgia, the country's largest grower and shipper of Vidalia onions, agreed to pay approximately $62,000 in back pay to to settle complaints of workplace discrimination against U.S. citizens. As part of the settlement agreement, Bland Farms also agreed to pay $15,000 in civil penalties to the government.

The Justice Department announced a settlement agreement under the Americans with Disabilities Act with Blockbuster Inc. to ensure equal access to its stores nationwide for individuals with disabilities who use service animals.

Company: Brickell Financial Services Motor Club, Inc., d/b/a Road America Motor Club, Inc.

Description: The Justice Department announced that C&F Mortgage Corporation of Midlothian, Va., agreed to revise its pricing policies, conduct employee training and pay $140,000 as part of a settlement to resolve allegations that it engaged in a pattern or practice of discrimination on the basis of race and national origin.

The Justice Department reached a settlement agreement with Canvas Corporation, a vending company based in Woodbury, N.Y., to settle allegations that Canvas Corporation engaged in a pattern or practice of citizenship status discrimination by preferring to hire only U.S. citizens.

Capital One N.A. and Capital One Bank (USA) N.A. have agreed to pay approximately $12 million to resolve a lawsuit by the Department of Justice alleging the companies violated the Servicemembers Civil Relief Act (SCRA). The settlement covered a range of conduct that violated the protections guaranteed service members by the SCRA, including wrongful foreclosures, improper repossessions of motor vehicles, wrongful court judgments, improper denials of the 6 percent interest rate the SCRA guarantees to service members on some credit card and car loans and insufficient 6 percent benefits granted on credit cards, car loans and other types of accounts.
The Justice Department and Carnival Corp. settlement agreement under the Americans with Disabilities Act to advance equal access for individuals with disabilities who travel on cruise ships.
The Justice Department announced an agreement with Centerplate Inc. resolving allegations that the company violated the anti-discrimination provision of the Immigration and Nationality Act.

The Justice Department announced that Charter Bank of Corpus Christi, Texas, would maintain uniform pricing policies and pay more than $165,000 as part of a settlement to resolve allegations that it engaged in a pattern or practice of discrimination on the basis of national origin.

The Justice Department filed a settlement agreement that resolved allegations that Chevy Chase Bank F.S.B. engaged in a pattern or practice of discrimination against qualified African-American and Hispanic borrowers in its home mortgage lending from 2006 through 2009.

Recap of Ownership Changes: Citizens Republic Bancorp merged with FirstMerit Bank in 2012; FirstMerit was acquired by Huntington Bancshares in 2016
Description: Citizens Republic Bancorp Inc. and Citizens Bank of Flint, Michigan agreed to open a loan production office in an African-American neighborhood in Detroit, invest approximately $3.6 million in Wayne County, Mich., and take other steps as part of a settlement to resolve allegations that they engaged in a pattern or practice of discrimination on the basis of race and color.

The Justice Department reached an agreement with Commercial Cleaning Systems, a janitorial services company with headquarters in Denver, resolving claims that the company discriminated against work-authorized non-U.S. citizens in violation of the Immigration and Nationality Act.

Community State Bank of St. Charles, Mich., agreed to open a loan production office in an African-American neighborhood in Saginaw, Mich., invest $165,000 in majority African-American areas in and around Saginaw and take other steps as part of a settlement to resolve allegations that it engaged in a pattern or practice of discrimination on the basis of race.

Recap of Ownership Changes: PNC Financial Services acquired Compass Bank in 2021
Description: The Justice Department reached a settlement resolving allegations that Compass Bank of Birmingham, Ala., engaged in a pattern of lending discrimination against individuals based on their marital status.

The Justice Department reached an agreement with Constructor Services Inc., a construction company headquartered in the Atlanta, Georgia metropolitan area, resolving a claim that the company engaged in discriminatory documentary practices during the employment eligibility verification process in violation of the Immigration and Nationality Act.

COPOCO Community Credit Union, based in Bay City, Michigan, agreed to a settlement to resolve allegations that it illegally repossessed four servicemembers' vehicles. The DOJ lawsuit had alleged that COPOCO violated the Servicemembers Civil Relief Act by repossessing cars owned by protected servicemembers without first obtaining the required court orders. Under the agreement, COPOCO was required to change its policies and compensate four servicemembers whose cars COPOCO unlawfully repossessed.

The Department of Justice reached a settlement with Countrywide Financial Corporation and its subsidiaries to resolve allegations that they engaged in a widespread pattern or practice of discrimination against qualified African-American and Hispanic borrowers in their mortgage lending from 2004 through 2008.

The Justice Department reached an agreement with Crookham Company to resolve the department's allegations that the seed company discriminated against work-authorized non-U.S. citizens, in violation of the Immigration and Nationality Act.

The Justice Department reached an agreement with Culinaire International, a catering and restaurant management company headquartered in Houston, Texas, resolving a claim that Culinaire engaged in citizenship discrimination during the employment eligibility reverification process in violation of the Immigration and Nationality Act.

The Justice Department reached a settlement with The Data Entry Company Inc., a government subcontractor headquartered in Bethesda, Maryland, resolving a complaint filed with the Office of Special Counsel for Immigration-Related Unfair Employment Practices claiming that the company engaged in hiring discrimination in violation of the Immigration and Nationality Act.

The Justice Department reached an agreement with Diversified Business Consulting Group Inc., an information technology staffing agency headquartered in Silver Spring, Maryland resolving claims that it discriminated against work-authorized non-U.S. citizens in violation of the Immigration and Nationality Act.

The United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York announced a settlement to resolve allegations that the Durst Organization engaged in a pattern and practice of developing rental apartment buildings that are inaccessible to persons with disabilities.

The Justice Department filed a consent order to resolve allegations that Eagle Bank and Trust Company engaged in a pattern or practice of redlining predominantly African-American neighborhoods in and around St. Louis.

Secondary Offense: Uniformed Services Employment and Reemployment Rights Act
Description: The Department of Justice announced that it has entered into a consent decree with Ecolab Inc. resolving allegations that it failed to reemploy a Michigan veteran in violation of the Uniformed Services Employment and Reemployment Rights Act of 1994.

The Justice Department announced that Evolve Bank & Trust agreed to maintain revised policies, conduct employee training and compensate victims to resolve allegations that it engaged in a pattern or practice of discrimination on the basis of disability and receipt of public assistance in violation of the Fair Housing Act and the Equal Credit Opportunity Act.

The Excalibur Hotel and Casino in Las Vegas agreed to pay more than $50,000 in civil penalties and back pay to settle allegations that it engaged in workplace discrimination by making improper document demands.

The Justice Department reached a settlement with First Lowndes Bank in Lowndes County, Ala., resolving allegations that the bank engaged in a pattern or practice of discrimination against African-American customers by charging them higher interest rates on manufactured housing loans, in violation of the Fair Housing Act and Equal Credit Opportunity Act.

The Justice Department announced that First United Bank, of Dimmitt, Texas, will maintain uniform pricing policies, conduct employee training and pay $140,000 as part of a settlement to resolve allegations that it engaged in a pattern or practice of discrimination on the basis of national origin.

GFI Mortgage Bankers Inc. agreed to pay $3.555 million to resolve a lending discrimination lawsuit filed by the Department of Justice and the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York.

The Department of Justice announced the settlement of its lawsuit against the Golden Corral restaurant in Westland, Mich., which alleged that the owners and operators of the Golden Corral violated the Americans with Disabilities Act  by denying service to a mother and her minor children based on the appearance of the children's skin due to a genetic skin disorder.

Secondary Offense: Uniformed Services Employment and Reemployment Rights Act
Description: The Justice Department reached a settlement, in the form of a consent decree, with the Goodyear Tire & Rubber Company resolving its lawsuit alleging  that the company violated the Uniformed Services Employment and Reemployment Rights Act of 1994 by failing to promptly reemploy an individual following his military service.

The Justice Department announced a settlement agreement with Grand Circle LLC, based in Boston, doing business as Grand Circle Travel, to resolve alleged violations of the Americans with Disabilities Act and ensure that persons with disabilities, including those who use wheelchairs or other mobility aids, are afforded full and equal access to the company's travel services and facilities.

Recap of Ownership Changes: FirstGroup sold Greyhound to FlixMobility (not a Violation Tracker parent) in 2021
Description: Under the terms of a consent decree filed by the Justice Department, Greyhound Lines Inc. was required to implement a series of systemic reforms to resolve allegations that it repeatedly violated the Americans with Disabilities Act.

The Justice Department announced a settlement resolving allegations that the GuideOne Mutual Insurance Company and two authorized agents discriminated because of religion when they advertised special benefits and discounts only to "churchgoers" and "persons of faith." Under the settlement, the defendants had to pay a total of $29,500 to three victims of discrimination, an additional $45,000 to the government as a civil penalty and stop the alleged discriminatory practices.

Company: Highland Management Group Inc. and Edina Park Apartments LLC
Description: The Justice Department announced a settlement of its lawsuit alleging that Highland Management Group Inc., Edina Park Apartments LLC, and Amy Koch violated the Fair Housing Act by discriminating against Somali prospective renters at Edina Park Apartments in Edina, Minn. a suburb of Minneapolis.

Recap of Ownership Changes: Hilton was taken private by Blackstone in 2007 and went public again in 2013
Description: The Justice Department reached a settlement with Hilton Worldwide resolving allegation that Hilton it discriminated against a foreign-born worker.  Specifically, the department found that a Hilton-owned hotel in Naples, Florida, discriminated against an asylee by improperly rejecting his Social Security card when the hotel reverified his employment authorization.

The Justice Department announced a settlement agreement with Hoover Inc., a leading manufacturer of vacuum and carpet cleaners with facilities in Ohio and Texas, to resolve allegations that Hoover engaged in a pattern or practice of employment discrimination by imposing unnecessary and discriminatory hurdles in the I-9 process upon lawful permanent residents.

Company: HRB Tax Group Inc., H&R Block Tax Services LLC and HRB Advance LLC
Description: The Justice Department announced a comprehensive settlement agreement under the Americans with Disabilities Act with HRB Tax Group Inc., H&R Block Tax Services LLC and HRB Advance LLC to ensure effective communication with individuals who are deaf or hard of hearing in the provision of income tax preparation services and courses at more than 11,000 owned and franchised offices nationwide.

HSBC Finance Corporation, as successor to HSBC Auto Finance Inc., agreed to pay $434,500 to resolve allegations that it violated the Servicemembers Civil Relief Act by repossessing 75 cars owned by protected servicemembers without obtaining the necessary court orders.

The Justice Department reached an agreemenwith International Business Machines Corporation resolving allegations that the company violated the anti-discrimination provision of the Immigration and Nationality Act when it placed online job postings for application and software developers that contained citizenship status preferences for F-1 and H-1B temporary visa holders.

The Department of Justice announced that iGate Mastech Inc., a Pittsburgh computer consulting company, agreed to pay $45,000 in civil penalties to settle allegations that iGate discriminated against United States citizens in its employment practices.

The Justice Department reached an agreement with Infinity Group and its related entities resolving allegations that the companies violated the anti-discrimination provision of the Immigration and Nationality Act.

The Justice Department reached a settlementto resolve the department's claims that J.E.T. Holding Co. Inc. discriminated against U.S. citizens and certain work-authorized immigrants in violation of the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA).

The Justice Department reached a settlement with La Farine Bakery, a bakery with two stores in the San Francisco Bay Area, resolving allegations that it violated the Immigration and Nationality Act by engaging in discriminatory documentary practices.

The Justice Department reached a settlement with Life Generations Healthcare LLC, doing business as Generations Healthcare (GHC), following an administrative court decision finding that GHC engaged in a pattern and practice of discrimination against individuals born abroad, including naturalized U.S. citizens, in violation of the Immigration and Nationality Act.

Lincoln Military Housing, which owns and operates dozens of on-base and off-base military housing communities throughout Southern California, agreed to pay $200,000 to resolve allegations that it unlawfully evicted active-duty servicemembers and their families by obtaining default judgments against them, in violation of the Servicemembers Civil Relief Act.
The Justice Department reached a settlement with Louisiana Crane & Construction LLC resolving alleged violations of the Immigration and Nationality Act.

The Justice Department reached an agreement with Luis Esparza Services, Inc., a farm labor contractor company based in Bakersfield, California, resolving claims that the company discriminated against individuals because of citizenship status in violation of the Immigration and Nationality Act.

The Justice Department announced that Luther Burbank Savings agreed to invest $2 million in California communities and take other steps as part of a settlement to resolve allegations that it engaged in a pattern or practice of discrimination on the basis of race and national origin.

The Justice Department reached an agreement with Macy's over allegations that the large national retailer violated the Immigration and Nationality Act by discriminating against work-authorized non-U.S. citizens at its Glendale, California, location.

The Justice Department reached a settlement with Marriott International and one of the Iowa hotels it manages to resolve allegations of discrimination against Arab, Muslim Sikh or South Asian Americans.

The Justice Department reached an agreement with Master Klean Janitorial, a company based in Denver, resolving claims that the company engaged in a pattern or practice of discriminatory documentary requests based on citizenship status in violation of the Immigration and Nationality Act.

The Justice Departmentreached a settlement with McDonald's USA LLC and its corporate affiliates and subsidiaries resolving allegations that the company discriminated against immigrant employees of McDonald's-owned restaurants.

The Justice Department today reached a settlement with the Medical Weight Loss Clinic, which is headquartered in Southfield, Mich., under the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA). It was alleged that Medical Weight Loss Clinic refused to serve a prospective client because she had HIV disease.

Company: Megabus USA L.L.C., and Megabus Northeast L.L.C.
Description: The Justice Department announced a comprehensive settlement agreement under the Americans with Disabilities Act with intercity bus service providers Megabus USA L.L.C., and Megabus Northeast L.L.C.

Company: Mexico Foods LLC, aka El Rancho Corp.
Description: The Justice Department reached an agreementwith Mexico Foods LLC, aka El Rancho Corp., a supermarket chain based in Garland, Texas, resolving claims that the company engaged in discrimination during the employment eligibility verification process in violation of the Immigration and Nationality Act.

The Justice Department announced an agreement with MicroLink Devices, a manufacturer of semiconductor structures and advanced solar cells based in Niles, Ill., resolving allegations that the company violated the anti-discrimination provision of the Immigration and Nationality Act when it placed six online job postings that explicitly stated citizenship status preferences or requirements that excluded certain work-authorized non-citizens from consideration.

Midwest BankCentre agreed to open a full-service branch in an African-American neighborhood and invest approximately $1.45 million in majority African-American areas of the St. Louis metropolitan area as part of a settlement to resolve allegations that it engaged in a pattern or practice of discrimination on the basis of race and color.

The Justice Department reached an agreement with Milestone Management Company, a nationwide residential property management firm headquartered in Dallas, resolving claims that the staffing company violated the anti-discrimination provision of the Immigration and Nationality Act.
The Department of Justice settled a lawsuit against the Mortgage Guaranty Insurance Corporation (MGIC) for discriminating against women on maternity leave in violation of the Fair Housing Act.

The Justice Department announced that Multi/Tech Engineering Services Inc., an engineering firm based in Salem, Ore., agreed to pay more than $60,000 to settle a lawsuit alleging that it had violated the Fair Housing Act by designing Gateway Village Apartments with steps and other features that made it inaccessible to people with disabilities.

Company: Nationwide Nevada, LLC and NAC Management Corp.
Description: The Justice Department reached a settlement resolving allegations that Nationwide Nevada, LLC, and its general partner NAC Management Corp., engaged in a pattern or practice of discrimination by refusing to finance car loans for customers living on Indian reservations in Utah and Nevada.

The Justice Department reached a settlement with Nebraska Beef Ltd. resolving an investigation by the Office of Special Counsel for Immigration-Related Unfair Employment Practices into whether the company was engaging in employment discrimination in violation of the Immigration and Nationality Act.

The Justice Department reached an agreement with NetJets Services Inc. resolving allegations that it violated the anti-discrimination provision of the Immigration and Nationality Act by discriminating against work-authorized immigrants.

Company: Nevada Yellow Cab Corporation, Nevada Checker Cab Corporation, and Nevada Star Cab Corporation
Description: The Justice Department reached an agreement with Nevada Yellow Cab Corporation, Nevada Checker Cab Corporation, and Nevada Star Cab Corporation -- three Las Vegas, Nevada, taxicab companies that collectively operate under the umbrella company Yellow Checker Star Transportation Company -- resolving claims that YCS discriminated against work-authorized immigrants because of their citizenship status.

The Department of Justice announced reached a settlement with New Century Travel, Inc. under the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) enforcing the ADA's requirement that over-the-road discount bus service be accessible for persons with disabilities. The company paid a $5,000 penalty and $1,000 to disabled customers.

The Justice Department announced that Nixon State Bank of Nixon, Texas, agreed to establish uniform pricing policies, conduct employee training, and pay nearly $100,000 as part of a settlement to resolve allegations that it engaged in a pattern or practice of discrimination on the basis of national origin.

The Justice Department announced an agreement with North American Shipbuilding LLC resolving a complaint filed with the Justice Department's Office of Special Counsel for Immigration-Related Unfair Employment Practices claiming that the company retaliated against an individual for filing a charge of discrimination.

Company: North Carolina Agricultural & Technical State University
Description: The Justice Department entered into a consent decree with the University of North Carolina and its constituent institution, North Carolina Agricultural & Technical State University, to resolve a complaint of employment discrimination that was filed by the United States against the University under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, as amended.

The Justice Department announced a consent decree with Norwegian Cruise Line to resolve a lawsuit under the Americans with Disabilities Act on behalf of individuals who are deaf or hard of hearing, and individuals who use wheelchairs, who took NCL cruises of the Hawaiian Islands.

The Justice Department reached a settlement with Onward Healthcare, a healthcare staffing company based in Wilton, Conn., resolving allegations that the company posted discriminatory job advertisements on its home page and third party websites that limited its jobs to U.S. citizens.

The Justice Department reached a settlement agreement with Panda Restaurant Group, Inc. , a restaurant chain with over 1,800 locations, resolving an investigation into whether it discriminated against non-U.S. citizens in violation of the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA) when reverifying their permission to work.

Company: Paragon Building Maintenance, Inc. and Pegasus Building Services Company, Inc.
Description: The Justice Department reached an agreement with Paragon Building Maintenance, Inc. and Pegasus Building Services Company, Inc., related janitorial companies headquartered in Long Beach, California. The settlement resolved the department's investigation into whether the companies violated the Immigration and Nationality Act by discriminating against work-authorized immigrants when checking their work authorization documents.

The Justice Department announced an agreement with Paramount Staffing, a staffing company based in Northbrook, Ill., resolving an allegation that the company violated the anti-discrimination provision of the Immigration and Nationality Act by requesting more or different documents from individuals during the employment eligibility verification processes based on the individuals' citizenship status.

The Justice Department reached a settlement agreement with Pizzerias, LLC, a pizza restaurant franchisee with 31 locations in Miami, Florida resolving the department's investigation into whether it violated the Immigration and Nationality Act by discriminating against work-authorized immigrants when checking their work authorization documents.

The Justice Department announced that Plaza Home Mortgage Inc.  of San Diego agreed to pay $3 million to aggrieved borrowers as part of a settlement to resolve allegations that it engaged in a pattern or practice of discrimination on the basis of race and national origin.

The Justice Department reached an agreement with Potter Concrete, a company based in Dallas, resolving claims that the company engaged in a pattern or practice of document abuse in violation of the Immigration and Nationality Act.

The Justice Department reached an agreement Powerstaffing Inc., a temporary staffing agency, resolving  allegations that Powerstaffing's North Bergen, New Jersey office discriminated against work-authorized non-U.S. citizens in violation of the Immigration and Nationality Act.

PrimeLending, a national mortgage lender, agreed to pay $2 million to resolve allegations that it engaged in a pattern or practice of discrimination against African-American borrowers between 2006 and 2009.

The Justice Department announced the payment of more than $1.5 million in damages under a consent decree previously reached with QuikTrip Corporation. The payments were made by QuikTrip to compensate 47 individuals with disabilities who experienced discrimination at QuikTrip gas stations and convenience stores across the country, in violation of Title III of the Americans with Disabilities Act.

The Justice Department announced a comprehensive settlement under the Americans with Disabilities Act with QuikTrip Corporation, owner and operator of gas stations, convenience stores, travel centers, and truck stops in the Midwest, South and Southwestern United States.

The Justice Department announced that the operator and manager of the Rathbone Retirement Community in Evansville, Ind., agreed to pay up to $116,000 to resolve a housing discrimination lawsuit. The November 2008 lawsuit alleged that the defendants violated the Fair Housing Act by prohibiting the use of motorized wheelchairs and scooters in residents' apartments and in the home's common dining room during meals.

The Justice Department reached an agreement with Real Time Staffing Services LLC, doing business as Select Staffing, a company based in Santa Barbara, California, resolving the department's claims that Select Staffing discriminated against work-authorized non-U.S. citizens in violation of the Immigration and Nationality Act.

The Justice Department announced that, as part of its Barrier-Free Health Care Initiative, it reached a settlement with Rite Aid of Michigan to resolve claims that Rite Aid violated the Americans with Disabilities Act.

The Justice Department reached an agreement with Ross Stores Inc. resolving allegations that the company had engaged in a pattern or practice of discrimination based on citizenship status while verifying employment eligibility at its store in San Ysidro, Calif.

The Justice Department filed a complaint and proposed consent order to resolve allegations that Sage Bank, headquartered in Lowell, Massachusetts, violated the Fair Housing Act and the Equal Credit Opportunity Act by engaging in a pattern or practice of discrimination on the basis of race and national origin in the pricing of its residential mortgage loans.

The Department of Justice announced the federal government's first lawsuit filed against owners and servicers of student loans for violating the rights of servicemembers eligible for benefits and protections under the Servicemembers Civil Relief Act.  The complaint alleged that three defendants engaged in a nationwide pattern or practice, dating as far back as 2005, of violating the SCRA by failing to provide members of the military the six percent interest rate cap to which they were entitled.  The three defendants were Sallie Mae Inc. (later known as Navient Solutions Inc.), SLM DE Corporation (later known as Navient DE Corporation), and Sallie Mae Bank.  The complaint further alleged that defendants Sallie Mae Inc. and SLM DE Corporation also violated the SCRA by improperly obtaining default judgments against servicemembers.

Santander Consumer USA Inc. agreed to pay at least $9.35 million to resolve a lawsuit by the Department of Justice alleging that the motor vehicle lender violated the Servicemembers Civil Relief Act through improper repossessions.

Company: SD Staffing LLC aka Atwork Personnel Services Inc.

The Justice Department reached an agreement with Sellari's Enterprises, Inc. , a company that provides staffing services in Orlando, Florida, resolving an investigation into whether its violated the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA) by discriminating against work-authorized immigrants when verifying their work authorization.

Company: Serendipity Hearing Inc. dba Sonus Hearing Care
Description: The Justice Department announced an agreement with Serendipity Hearing Inc., doing business as Sonus Hearing Care, a hearing services provider headquartered in the Los Angeles, California, metropolitan area.  The agreement resolved a claim, filed with the Office of Special Counsel for Immigration-Related Unfair Employment Practices, that the company violated the Immigration and Nationality Act by engaging in discriminatory documentary practices during the employment eligibility verification process.

The Justice Department reached an agreement with SK Food Group Inc., a company based in Seattle, resolving claims that the company used discriminatory document practices when verifying the work authority of non-citizens.

Secondary Offense: Uniformed Services Employment and Reemployment Rights Act
Description: The Justice Department announced a settlement resolving allegations that SmallTownPapers Inc. violated the Uniformed Services Employment and Reemployment Rights Act of 1994 when it terminated an employee due to his military obligation as an Air Force Reservist to attend active duty training.

The Justice Department reached an agreement with SOS Employment Group, based in Salt Lake City resolving claims that the company violated the anti-discrimination provision of the Immigration and Nationality Act.

The Justice Department announced that Southport Bank of Kenosha, Wis., agreed to pay $687,000 to African-American and Hispanic wholesale mortgage borrowers as part of a settlement to resolve allegations that it engaged in a pattern or practice of discrimination on the basis of race and national origin.

Sunny Grove  Landscaping & Nursery Inc., a landscaping company  in Ft. Myers, Florida, agreed to pay $7,500 to resolve allegations of discrimination against work-authorized non-U.S. citizens in violation of the Immigration and Nationality Act.

Recap of Ownership Changes: SunTrust Banks and BB&T merged and formed Truist Financial in 2019
Description: SunTrust Mortgage Inc. agreed to pay $21 million to resolve a lawsuit by the Department of Justice alleging that it engaged in a pattern or practice of discrimination that increased loan prices for many of the qualified African-American and Hispanic borrowers.
Meatpacker Swift & Company agreed to pay $174,088 in civil penalties and $13,412 in back wages to settle allegations that it engaged in citizenship status discrimination.

Secondary Offense: Uniformed Services Employment and Reemployment Rights Act
Description: The Justice Department reached a settlement with Symphony Diagnostic Services Inc., doing business as MobilexUSA , resolving allegations that it failed to reemploy a discharged member of the U.S. Army.

The Justice Department an agreement with TEG Staffing Inc., also known as Eastridge Workforce Solutions, a temporary staffing agency headquartered in San Diego, to resolve allegations that their Mira Mesa, California, office discriminated against work-authorized non-U.S. citizens in violation of the Immigration and Nationality Act.

The Justice Department announced that Texas Champion Bank of Alice, Texas, will establish uniform pricing policies, conduct employee training and pay $700,000 as part of a settlement to resolve allegations that it engaged in a pattern or practice of discrimination on the basis of national origin.

The Justice Department and the Department of Transportation announced $55,000 in fines against Tornado Bus Company Inc., of Dallas, for violating passenger carrier accessibility requirements under the Americans with Disabilities Act.

Company: Townhomes of Kings Lake HOA Inc. and Vanguard Management Group Inc.
Description: The Justice Department announcedthat the Townhomes of Kings Lake HOA Inc. and Vanguard Management Group Inc. agreed to pay $150,000 to settle a lawsuit alleging that they discriminated against families with children.

A Maryland food processing plant that required certain work authorization documents from some, but not all, employees agreed to pay $97,000 in civil penalties and contribute $135,000 to a worker security fund to settle discrimination complaints filed by the Justice Department and a union on behalf of more than 660 legal immigrant workers.

The Justice Department reached an agreement with Travel Management Company, a private airplane charter company based in Elkhart, Indiana, resolving claims that the company engaged in citizenship status discrimination in violation of the Immigration and Nationality Act.

The Justice Department announced a settlement under the Americans with Disabilities Act with Trinity Health Systems to ensure that Trinity Regional Medical Center in Fort Dodge, Iowa, provides effective communication to individuals who are deaf or hard of hearing.

Tropicana Hotel & Casino in Atlantic City, New Jersey, under an agreement reached with the Department of Justice, agreed to pay $75,000 in civil penalties to settle allegations of workplace discrimination.

The Justice Department reached an agreement with Tuscany Hotel and Casino LLC in Las Vegas resolving a lawsuit alleging that the company discriminated in the employment eligibility verification and re-verification process.

The United States settled a lawsuit alleging that an automobile dealership formerly doing business in Los Angeles violated the Equal Credit Opportunity Act by charging non-Asian customers higher interest rate markups than other customers for a period of at least three years.

Company: Union Savings Bank and Guardian Savings Bank
Description: The Justice Department filed a consent order to resolve allegations that Union Savings Bank and Guardian Savings Bank engaged in a pattern or practice of redlining predominantly African-American neighborhoods in and around Cincinnati; Columbus, Ohio; Dayton, Ohio; and Indianapolis.

The Justice Department reached an agreement with United Continental Holdings Inc. resolving a claim that divisions of the company previously operating as Continental Airlines discriminated against individuals because of citizenship status in violation of the Immigration and Nationality Act.

The Justice Department announced a settlement agreement with U.S. Service Industries, a janitorial company, resolving allegations that USSI violated the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA) by discriminating against work-authorized individuals who are not U.S. citizens.

The Justice Department reached a settlement agreement with Villa Rancho Bernardo Care Center, a skilled nursing facility in San Diego, resolving the department's investigation of VRB for discrimination against work-authorized non-U.S. citizens in violation of the Immigration and Nationality Act.
The Justice Department announced an agreement with Vincent Porcaro Inc. resolving allegations that the company violated the anti-discrimination provision of the Immigration and Nationality Act.

Description: The Justice Department entered into a consent decree with Wagner Industrial Electric Inc. resolving allegations that the company failed to properly reemploy an Indiana Army National Guard Reservist in violation of the Uniformed Services Employment and Reemployment Rights Act of 1994.

The Justice Department announced a $1.25 million agreement with Warren Properties Inc., Warren Village (Mobile) Limited Partnership and Frank R. Warren to settle allegations that the defendants violated the Fair Housing Act by refusing to grant a tenant's requests for a reasonable accommodation.

Company: Washington Potato Company and Pasco Processing, LLC
